intro: Sida poeppigiana, commonly known as the yellow mallow, is a herbaceous plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, often attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Sida poeppigiana is also known for its medicinal properties, used traditionally in some cultures for its purported health benefits.
